s.text: The Post reports, based on several unnamed well-placed Pentagon sources, that unlike in the Gulf War, the preponderance of planned strikes are now targeted against so-called "leadership" targets: not so much air defense sites or depots, as, for example, secret police headquarters.
In the latest USAT /CNN/Gallup Poll, 76 percent of respondents approve of air strikes, while 60 percent go beyond the Clinton administration and also support the use of ground troops against Iraq.
It's only when the reader digs out the Sunday article that he learns the headline referred to Saddam's death as a Gulf War "goal."
Such agreements, says the paper, have allowed the president's defense team to learn what questions are being posed and what answers given during grand jury sessions.
The paper suggests that both Clinton's secretary Betty Currie and White House steward Bayani Nelvis have entered into such agreements with BC.

Witness today's correction in the WP : "In an article Sunday, former CIA director Robert M. Gates said that during the 1991 Persian Gulf War, U.S. officials were "hoping" that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would be killed in a bombing raid.
